Lastly, 5! is not SUM(5 x 1, 5 x 2, 5x3,5x4,5x5). It's SUM(1 x 2 x 3 x 4 x 5)
@max77p also don't forget it's good practice to declare your variables e.g. `for (*var* i = 0; i < num; i++)`

The first time your loop runs `num = num x i` `(num = 5 x 1 = 5)`
The second time around, ` i =  2` so ` num = num x i (num = 5 x 2 = 10)`.
Your for loop has now changed to `for (i = 1; i < 10; i++)` and so on.

@matthewfarlymn Things I paid for I definitely keep. For example, maybe 4-5 years ago I've purchased a theme for WordPress - and I just kept the files because who knows! :)

I think what you're doing with photos is a great idea.
giant*

@Kallaway very true, I’ve also been concerned about things I’ve paid for (ex. stockphotos)… So I have a gian folder of stock photos which is a nightmare to search through, but I don’t have to worry about paying for something and it not being available when I need it
then the gigantic folder with files "just in case" can just be put on an external hard drive and forgotten about :) so long as it's not on my laptop I am happy
@matthewfarlymn that's exactly what my reasoning is - what ifs :)

@matthewfarlymn @tomsun100 I used to keep a lot of things, but in my efforts to not become a digital hoarder :) I am always trying to declutter my laptop (and other devices with storage). However, if a resource takes too much time to find, or requires "filling the form" to download, or likely to not be available in the future (say a certain version of a product, or a software product of a company that is planning to close down) I will definitely keep it. :)
@tomsun100 very true, I guess I have this fear that development will stop or the download will cease to exist LOL

@matthewfarlymn A lot of the plugins, libraries, and templates are available online and just a google search away. It's not really that necessary to keep every a copy of JQuery unless you need it for performance issues.
@Kallaway awesome, so you don’t actually keep the files, just links to the downloads?

For any kind of text info, I use Evernote, but for everything like lists of movies, books, plugins, coding resources, ideas, etc. - I user boards on Trello.com 

For habits, I use Coach.me (previously known as Lift) I don't like the changes they are making , but the core product is still very usable and free :)

RESOURCES, moved from the old Gitter channel:

4) by @matthewfarlymn "https://toronto.wordcamp.org/2015/ is a conference that takes place once a year (they have a meet up group that meets weekly to) focusing on development on the WordPress CMS platform. It’s a pretty informative conference that generally has a multitude of streams from beginner to advanced. Some really awesome information if you’re interested in dabbling with WordPress as your CMS of choice. I’ve also gone to DevTO meetups which are awesome as well. Don’t know too much regarding them specifically though. Just developers meeting and socializing."
